study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT)/Photobiomodulation Therapy (PBMT) in reducing the incidence and severity of oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the incidence of severe oral mucositis (grade ≥3) between the active laser group (54.8%) and the control group (43.9%), with a median time to occurrence of 8 weeks vs. 9 weeks, respectively. However, LLLT/PBMT was well tolerated, with 95% of patients showing very good tolerance.
population_specificity: Patients with oral cavity or oro/hypopharyngeal cancers (stage III or IV) undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ergogenic effects of PBMT (Low-Level Laser Therapy) during detraining after an aerobic endurance training protocol.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. It will analyze time until exhaustion, VO2max, and fat percentage.
population_specificity: Healthy male volunteers
study_duration: 12 weeks of training followed by 4 weeks of detraining

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether photobiomodulation (PBM) combined with mechanical debridement improves periodontal pocket outcomes in patients with periodontitis and type 2 diabetes compared to mechanical debridement alone.
results_summary: PBM did not significantly improve mean probing depth (PD) or clinical attachment level (CAL) over 12 months compared to mechanical therapy alone. However, PBM reduced the frequency of moderate periodontal pockets (5-6 mm) at 6 months and showed significant improvements in deeper pockets (≥7 mm) at multiple time points.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontitis and type 2 diabetes (19 patients, 38 periodontal pockets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for pain management after root canal treatment or retreatment.
results_summary: Three studies showed LLLT significantly reduced pain prevalence after root canal therapy or retreatment, while most studies found lower pain intensity in the LLLT group. Two of three studies assessing analgesic need reported significant benefits, though results varied across studies and observation times.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing root canal treatment or retreatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diode laser and indium-gallium-aluminum laser used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) as a complementary treatment to complete decongestive therapy (CDT) for relieving lymphedema symptoms in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced lymphedema symptoms and emotional distress compared to placebo, though limb volume reduction was not significant. Active LLLT led to fewer participants reporting multiple symptoms and improved mobility and emotional well-being.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients diagnosed with lymphedema and referred for CDT.
effective_dosage: Administered twice a week at the beginning of each CDT session (specific laser parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a single application of PBM-LLLT on nipple pain and damage in breastfeeding women and assess any side effects.
results_summary: The study found that PBM-LLLT was effective in relieving nipple pain and repairing damage in breastfeeding women, with side effects also being collected, though specific results on efficacy and safety were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Breastfeeding women with nipple damage who were exclusively breastfeeding and rooming-in at Amparo Maternal maternity service, São Paulo, Brazil.
effective_dosage: Single irradiation (660 nm, 100 mW, 2 J, 66.66 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of laser acupuncture treatment (LAT) in patients with inadequate recovery from chronic Bell's palsy.
results_summary: The study is a pilot trial, so definitive results are not yet available, but it compares real LAT with sham LAT to assess changes in facial disability and nerve grading systems over 6 weeks.
population_specificity: 32 patients with chronic Bell's palsy experiencing inadequate recovery.
effective_dosage: 3 LAT sessions per week for 6 weeks (total 18 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces pain after orthodontic archwire placement and whether its effectiveness varies based on the degree of dental crowding.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain intensity and duration compared to placebo and control groups, but its effectiveness did not vary with the degree of crowding. No differences were found between placebo and control groups.
population_specificity: 84 patients (41 male, 43 female) aged 13-30 with mandibular crowding ≥3 mm, no prior orthodontic treatment, and no lower arch spaces or ectopic teeth.
study_duration: Pain assessed from 2 hours to 7 days post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of photobiomodulation (LLLT) on hemodynamic parameters in hypertensive and normotensive patients, with the goal of improving treatment adherence and reducing morbidity and mortality.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not report results, as it appears to be a proposal for future research.
population_specificity: Forty-four participants, frequent attendees of an ambulatory university clinic, subdivided into hypertensive and normotensive groups.
study_duration: Not specified (protocol mentions sessions but no duration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the evidence for the therapeutic applications of light energy treatments, specifically Low-Level Laser Therapy, for wound healing.
results_summary: The study found that various doses and wavelengths of light energy treatments provided therapeutic benefits for chronic wounds, though there was a lack of consensus on standardized treatment parameters. Noninvasive and economical light devices were deemed attractive for wound management, but optimal clinical protocols need further development.
population_specificity: Human subjects with chronic wounds.
effective_dosage: 0.1 to 10 J/cm², wavelengths ranging from 405 to 1,000 nm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) promotes hair growth in male androgenetic alopecia (AGA) patients by analyzing protein expression changes in dermal papilla tissues.
results_summary: Proteomic analysis identified 11 up-regulated and 2 down-regulated proteins post-LLLT, implicating roles in cellular transcription, lipid homeostasis, extracellular matrix function, and angiogenesis. LLLT increased ECM proteins, leading to larger dermal papilla volume and improved hair diameter in AGA patients.
population_specificity: Male patients with androgenetic alopecia (AGA).
effective_dosage: 655 nm, 5 mW, 25 minutes per treatment every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on orthodontically-induced inflammatory root resorption (OIIRR).
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with some studies showing LLLT significantly reduces OIIRR during orthodontic tooth movement (OTM), while others reported increased OIIRR or no significant reparative effect. The overall influence of LLLT on OIIRR remains debatable.
population_specificity: Clinical and animal/experimental studies focusing on orthodontic tooth movement and root resorption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of selected biophysical energies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), in treating diabetic foot ulcers by analyzing cell studies and animal experiments.
results_summary: LLLT demonstrated a significant clinical benefit in reducing wound size compared to control or sham treatments, while ultrasound did not show significant effects. The study suggests potential benefits of LLLT in diabetic wound management but calls for further well-designed trials due to heterogeneity in current clinical studies.
population_specificity: Animal and cell studies focused on diabetic foot ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating adult androgenic alopecia (AGA) by comparing hair density changes between LLLT and sham devices.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant increase in hair density with LLLT compared to sham treatment, with greater effects observed in low-frequency treatment groups. LLLT was effective across genders, device types, and treatment durations.
population_specificity: Adults with androgenic alopecia (both male and female).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency subgroups: low vs. high, but exact dosages not detailed).
study_duration: Varied (short- and long-term treatment courses included).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) significantly relieves pain in patients with plantar fasciitis (PF) through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that LLLT significantly reduced pain (measured by VAS) at the end of treatment, with effects lasting up to 3 months, though no significant difference was observed using the FFI-p subscale.
population_specificity: Patients with plantar fasciitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on sensorineural recovery after split ramus osteotomy of the mandible.
results_summary: LLLT showed marked improvement in sensorineural recovery, particularly in the short postoperative period, with the best results observed in the fifth session. Both experimental and control sides improved, but the experimental side exhibited superior recovery.
population_specificity: Adult patients (mean age 35.6 years, 70% women) who underwent advanced mandibular surgery.
effective_dosage: 5 LLLT sessions with intervals of 3 to 4 weeks between sessions.
study_duration: Treatment duration varied: group 1 (short postoperative period, within 30 days) and group 2 (late postoperative period, 6 months to 1 year).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish recommendations for the correct use of photobiomodulation therapy (Low-Level Laser Therapy) for athletic performance enhancement and post-exercise recovery, based on the highest scientific evidence.
results_summary: The study highlights the growing clinical interest and research in photobiomodulation therapy, emphasizing the need for evidence-based guidelines. It references systematic reviews and randomized controlled trials to support its recommendations, advocating for future studies to maintain high scientific standards.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals seeking performance enhancement or post-exercise recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of photobiomodulation with low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in preventing and treating oral and oropharyngeal mucositis caused by radio-chemotherapy in patients with oral squamous cell carcinoma.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced the incidence and severity of mucositis, with 72.7% of the laser group showing normal mucosa (grade 0) by week 5 compared to 20.0% in the control group. No significant differences were observed in medication use or side effects between groups.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with oral squamous cell carcinoma undergoing radio-chemotherapy (average age 60.89±9.99 years).
study_duration: At least 5 weeks (until statistically significant differences were observed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and trunk stabilization exercises on sternotomy healing in post-CABG surgery patients.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced upper-sternal separation and was more effective than trunk stabilization exercises for the upper sternum, while trunk stabilization exercises were more effective for the lower sternum. Both interventions outperformed the control group in specific sternal regions.
population_specificity: 45 male patients aged 45-65 with acute sternal instability post-CABG surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in preventing chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis compared to other interventions.
results_summary: LLLT showed potential to prevent oral mucositis, particularly in reducing peak severity during follow-up, though the results lacked statistical significance. It performed comparably to an intensive oral care program in patients with oral erythema.
population_specificity: Patients aged 27-84 with solid tumors undergoing chemotherapy.
study_duration: Evaluated on the 7th and 14th days of chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the range of effective and ineffective parameters in Photobiomodulation (PBM) therapy, focusing on how different tissues respond to varying light doses.
results_summary: The study found that tissues with higher mitochondrial activity (e.g., muscle, brain) responded to lower light doses than those with lower mitochondrial activity (e.g., skin, tendon). Ineffective results in high-mitochondria tissues were often due to overdosing rather than underdosing.
population_specificity: In vitro cultured cells and in vivo tissues (muscle, brain, heart, nerve, skin, tendon, cartilage).
effective_dosage: Power density <100 mW/cm², energy density 4-10 J/cm² (some recommendations up to 50 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of low-level laser therapy for treating capsular contracture in women with breast reconstruction following mastectomy for breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in patient-reported outcomes or clinician-reported breast symmetry, shape, or naturalness between the active and placebo groups. However, the placebo group showed significantly greater improvement in clinician-reported breast softness and degree of contracture.
population_specificity: Women with breast reconstruction following mastectomy for breast cancer, including those who had postmastectomy radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Weekly treatments over 6 weeks with either an active or inactive low-level laser handpiece (Riancorp LTU-904).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current literature on Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) to understand its cellular and molecular effects and identify optimal characteristics for therapeutic benefits.
results_summary: The review suggests that LLLT may positively impact cellular viability, proliferation, DNA integrity, and repair, but acknowledges controversy in mainstream medicine and calls for a revised approach to maximize benefits while minimizing risks.
population_specificity: Mammalian models (not human-specific).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) significantly improved neurosensory recovery in patients with iatrogenic nerve injuries compared to a placebo group.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in neurosensory improvement between LLLT (46.7%) and placebo (38.5%) groups, regardless of the affected nerve or time from injury to treatment. The results did not support LLLT's efficacy for this specific application.
population_specificity: 35 patients with iatrogenic nerve injuries (inferior alveolar or lingual nerve) from third molar odontectomy, dental implant placement, or local anesthetic injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and evidence-based recommendations for Low-Level Laser Therapy (photobiomodulation) in treating chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN).
results_summary: Low-Level Laser Therapy was considered of moderate benefit based on the evidence review, though most studies had small sample sizes and short follow-up periods. No studies were prematurely closed due to adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain relief and other outcomes in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: LLLT did not significantly reduce pain (VAS scores) but significantly reduced the number of tender points and improved Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) scores. The study concluded that LLLT had a partial effect on pain relief in fibromyalgia patients.
population_specificity: Adults with fibromyalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of various therapies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for pain relief in patients with plantar fasciitis.
results_summary: LLLT showed a significant reduction in pain (VAS) compared to placebo at 0-6 weeks, but its long-term efficacy (2-12 months) was not significantly different from placebo due to wide confidence intervals. The study suggested LLLT may be a potential alternative, though further evidence is needed.
population_specificity: 1676 patients with plantar fasciitis.
study_duration: Effects assessed at 0-6 weeks, 2-4 months, and 6-12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and botulinum toxin A (BT-A) in treating chronic migraine by evaluating pain days, pain intensity, medication intake, anxiety, and sleep disorders.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT reduced headache days, acute medication intake, and pain intensity, and improved sleep disturbances, with comparable effectiveness to BT-A. Anxiety reduction was noted only in the BT-A group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic migraine (n = 18 in the LLLT group).
study_duration: 30 days of treatment, with additional pre- and post-treatment phases of 30 days each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on coronary tissues, particularly for patients with chronic stable angina and ischemic heart conditions.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that LLLT, especially in the NIR spectrum, may have protective effects on the heart post-myocardial infarction or in ischemic conditions not treatable by current revascularization methods, with a low side effect profile.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic stable angina, acute myocardial infarction, or ischemic heart conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) combined with resistance training improves muscle mass, strength, and functional capacity in elderly men compared to placebo.
results_summary: Both PBMT and placebo groups showed significant improvements in most outcomes, with no additional benefits from PBMT. Large effect sizes were observed for strength and functional tests, but muscle thickness improvements were small.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly men aged 60-80 years.
effective_dosage: 850 nm, 240 J per limb applied before each training session (2×/week).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing dental pain during cavity preparation in adults with permanent teeth.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain intensity by 42% in the test group compared to 16% in the control group (P<0.0001), suggesting it may reduce the need for pharmacological pain control during dental procedures.
population_specificity: 24 adult subjects with dental caries requiring class I restorations and a baseline pain score of ≥7 but <10 on a VAS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of photobiomodulation with low-level laser therapy (PBM-LLLT) combined with 5% potassium nitrate (KNO₃) on tooth sensitivity (TS) after dental bleaching.
results_summary: The study found that PBM-LLLT and KNO₃ reduced tooth sensitivity compared to the control group, with TS manifesting only on the days of bleaching sessions in treated groups, unlike the control group where TS lasted up to 3 days post-bleaching. Intergroup analysis showed significant differences between the control and treated groups but no significant differences among the treated groups.
population_specificity: Fifty volunteers meeting inclusion/exclusion criteria, divided into four groups.
study_duration: Evaluated on the 1st, 8th, and 15th days post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether photobiomodulation (Low-Level Laser Therapy) accelerates bone healing in extraction sockets.
results_summary: The study found consistent improvements in bone repair, including higher concentrations of osteogenesis markers (Ocn and Runx2), increased bone trabeculae percentage, and bone density. No side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Humans (3 studies), rats (5 studies), and rabbits (2 studies), either healthy or with specified systemic conditions.
effective_dosage: Laser parameters varied significantly between studies (not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for improving pain and physical function in patients with knee osteoarthritis, compared to other non-pharmacological and non-surgical interventions.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT did not improve patients' pain or physical function, differing from previous umbrella reviews. The evidence quality for LLLT was insufficient to support its use for knee osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Humans with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could reduce skeletal muscle fatigue in patients with heart failure (HF) by analyzing electrical activation in the quadriceps muscle.
results_summary: The study found that a single application of LLLT did not decrease skeletal muscle activation or reduce muscle fatigue in patients with HF, as measured by electromyography. No significant effects were observed across the fatigue protocols tested.
population_specificity: Fourteen patients diagnosed with heart failure (HF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the adjuvant effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on healing tendon injury in patients undergoing flexor tendon repair surgery.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly increased passive range of motion (PROM), significantly reduced pain, and led to high patient satisfaction compared to the control group. No ruptures were observed in either group during the 4-week follow-up.
population_specificity: 97 patients (114 fingers) with sharp hand injuries in three zones, divided into LLLT (39 patients, 46 fingers) and control (38 patients, 46 fingers) groups.
effective_dosage: 8-10 sessions of LLLT (red and infrared lasers) over the flexor tendon repaired area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) on performance and recovery in professional futsal players.
results_summary: PBMT significantly increased time spent on the pitch and improved biochemical markers (creatine kinase, lactate dehydrogenase, blood lactate, oxidative damage), but did not significantly affect distance covered.
population_specificity: Six professional futsal athletes.
effective_dosage: 30 J per site at 17 sites per lower limb, using a cluster with 12 diodes (4 laser diodes of 905 nm, 4 LEDs of 875 nm, and 4 LEDs of 640 nm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of laser photobiomodulation (PBM) and topical ozone therapy on palatal wound healing and patient morbidity after free gingival graft surgeries.
results_summary: The study found that ozone therapy significantly accelerated palatal wound healing compared to the control group at day 14. Both PBM and ozone therapy reduced postoperative discomfort compared to spontaneous healing.
population_specificity: 36 patients requiring free gingival grafts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on wound healing, free gingival graft shrinkage, and postoperative pain.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced graft shrinkage at 3 and 6 months and improved postoperative pain relief compared to placebo, but showed no significant difference in epithelization over 28 days.
population_specificity: 30 patients undergoing free gingival graft procedures.
effective_dosage: 810 nm diode laser, 0.1 W, energy density 6 J/cm².
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) is more effective than SRP alone in treating aggressive periodontitis (AgP).
results_summary: Three of four studies showed significant improvement in periodontal outcomes with LLLT compared to SRP alone, while one study found comparable results. The overall clinical attachment level gain was not significant, but probing depth reduction showed a significant difference favoring LLLT. The efficacy of LLLT remains debatable, requiring further research.
population_specificity: Patients with aggressive periodontitis (AgP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effect of PBMT (using combined lasers, LEDs, and magnetic field) on muscle performance, exercise tolerance, and metabolic variables during the 6-minute stepper test in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that PBMT with combined lasers, LEDs, and magnetic field may improve muscle performance and exercise tolerance in COPD patients during the 6MST, though specific results and statistical significance are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Twenty-one patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and high-intensity laser therapy (HILT) in patients with lumbar disc degenerative changes, comparing short- and long-term results with placebo.
results_summary: The study found that both HILT and LLLT showed therapeutic progress but no statistically significant differences compared to placebo, concluding these methods were ineffective for lumbar disc degenerative changes in both short- and long-term perspectives.
population_specificity: 68 participants with lumbar disc degenerative changes.
effective_dosage: HILT of 1,064 nm, 60 J/cm (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could enhance the repair of orthodontically induced inflammatory root resorption (OIIRR).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in OIIRR repair between the LLLT-treated side and the sham control group, indicating LLLT did not improve root resorption repair under the tested conditions.
population_specificity: Twenty patients requiring bilateral maxillary first premolar extractions as part of fixed appliance treatment.
effective_dosage: Weekly applications using a continuous beam 660-nm, 75-mW aluminum-gallium-indium-phosphorus laser (specific energy dose not detailed).
study_duration: 6 weeks (retention period after 4 weeks of force application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy and shockwave therapy on pain, neck functionality, and quality of life in patients with myofascial pain syndrome of the trapezius.
results_summary: Low-Level Laser Therapy significantly improved pain, neck functionality, and quality of life, though shockwave therapy showed greater benefits in most parameters except resting pain at week 15, where laser therapy was superior.
population_specificity: 61 patients (>18 years) with myofascial pain syndrome of the trapezius.
effective_dosage: Soft laser therapy once daily for 3 weeks (15 sessions total).
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 15 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain, trismus, and swelling in patients undergoing impacted third molar surgery.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain compared to placebo and control groups, particularly on day 7, but no significant differences were found in edema and trismus among the groups. The study also noted LLLT reduced facial swelling, though without statistical significance.
population_specificity: Forty-five patients over 17 years of age undergoing impacted third molar surgery.
effective_dosage: 0.3 W, 40 s, 4 J/cm² (single dose immediately after surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on postoperative pain in patients with symptomatic apical periodontitis after root canal treatment.
results_summary: LLLT resulted in significantly lower pain levels compared to control and placebo groups on days 1 and 3, but no significant differences were observed in postoperative percussion pain levels among the groups.
population_specificity: Forty-two patients with symptomatic apical periodontitis in mandibular molar teeth.
study_duration: Pain levels were recorded up to 30 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) combined with 5000 ppm fluoride dentifrice in reducing postbleaching sensitivity in teeth exposed to 35% hydrogen peroxide.
results_summary: The study found that teeth treated with LLLT and sodium fluoride showed significantly less sensitivity compared to those treated with fluoride alone, with statistical significance (P ≤ .05). The combination therapy improved symptoms of dentin sensitivity during bleaching sessions.
population_specificity: 25 volunteers evaluated using a split-mouth model.
effective_dosage: 60 J/cm² applied at two points per tooth (central cervical and medial regions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effect of three different doses of PBMT on maximal handgrip strength in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: PBMT significantly increased handgrip strength at doses of 60 J/arm (4.85%) and 90 J/arm (4.45%), but not with placebo or 120 J/arm. The 60 J/arm dose was identified as the most effective for enhancing small muscle strength.
population_specificity: CKD patients (15 volunteers, 58±8 years, 10 male/5 female) undergoing chronic hemodialysis treatment (6±4 years).
effective_dosage: 60 J/arm, 90 J/arm, and 120 J/arm (total doses per arm).
study_duration: Four hemodialysis sessions with 1-week intervals between evaluations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and feasibility of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunctive treatment for patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PPCI).
results_summary: LLLT was found to be safe with no adverse effects reported. It showed potential benefits, including significantly lower Troponin-T levels compared to the control group, though other outcomes like door-to-balloon time and left-ventricular ejection fraction did not show significant differences.
population_specificity: Patients with STEMI undergoing PPCI.
effective_dosage: 100 seconds of laser therapy applied to the tibia bone prior to PPCI, and again at 24 and 72 hours post-PPCI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a 940-nm diode laser in reducing post-operative pain and analgesic use after undisplaced flap surgery.
results_summary: Patients reported significantly less pain on days 2-7 and used fewer analgesics on days 3-7 in the laser-treated group compared to the control group. The 940-nm diode laser demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in pain and analgesic consumption post-surgery.
population_specificity: 30 patients requiring periodontal flap surgery for periodontal pockets on the same tooth on both sides of the mandible.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only wavelength and laser type mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness and safety of low-level laser therapy (He-Ne laser) on post-burn hypertrophic scar tissue in children.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in scar appearance and texture (measured by VSS and ultrasonography) in laser-treated areas compared to controls, with no adverse effects or differences in blood perfusion.
population_specificity: 15 children aged 2-10 years with post-burn hypertrophic scars.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of single low-level laser therapy (LLLT) irradiation on pain perception in orthodontic patients undergoing fixed appliance treatment.
results_summary: LLLT was effective in reducing pain immediately after treatment and separation, with the laser group reporting significantly lower pain (1.1) compared to the placebo group (1.6). However, no differences were observed after 24 hours, and gender-specific pain differences were noted in the placebo group after the first irradiation and in the laser group after 48 hours.
population_specificity: 62 patients undergoing fixed appliance treatment in orthodontics.
study_duration: Intervention applied before separation, 24 and 48 hours after separation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain and somatosensory sensitization induced by orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study compared LLLT (810-nm gallium-aluminium-arsenic diode laser) to a placebo in orthodontic patients, suggesting potential pain relief effects, though full results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 40 individuals aged 12-33 years (mean 20.8 ± 5.9 years) scheduled for orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: 810-nm laser in continuous mode at 400 mW, 2 J·cm (specific frequency not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) enhances bone formation and remodeling after maxillary sinus floor augmentation using a combination of autogenous bone and hydroxyapatite.
results_summary: LLLT did not increase new bone formation but accelerated bone remodeling, with no significant differences in vital bone presence or immunohistochemical markers between treated and untreated groups. A reduction in remaining biomaterial was observed in the LLLT group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing maxillary sinus floor augmentation with autogenous bone and hydroxyapatite.
effective_dosage: Gallium-aluminium-arsenide laser (830 nm, 40 mW, 5.32 J/point, 0.57 W/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of phototherapy (including Low-Level Laser Therapy) in managing creatine kinase (CK) activity after exercise and identify which exercise protocols yielded the best results.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that phototherapy had a more positive effect than control conditions in managing CK activity, particularly in localized exercise protocols with a large effect size, while general exercise protocols showed less consistent benefits.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects with no restrictions on age, sex, or exercise level.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy on preventing initial fatigue and aiding recovery of masticatory muscles (masseter and anterior temporal) after induced exhaustion in young adults.
results_summary: The study compared active laser therapy, sham laser, and no intervention, measuring time until muscle exhaustion via electromyography. Results suggested potential benefits of laser therapy in delaying fatigue, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 78 healthy male and female volunteers aged 18-34.
effective_dosage: Wavelength: 780 nm; fluence: 134 J/cm²; power: 50 mW; irradiance: 1.675 W/cm²; exposure time: 80 seconds per point (3 points on masseter, 1 on anterior temporal muscles per side).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current treatment approaches for Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS), including Low-Level Laser Therapy, and explore its potential efficacy and underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The abstract mentions Low-Level Laser Therapy as one of several treatment options for BMS, but does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes for this therapy. It highlights the lack of evidence-based treatment strategies for BMS overall.
population_specificity: Patients with Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS), particularly those with a striking female predilection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) combined with a functional exercise program on the treatment of fibromyalgia (FM).
results_summary: The study compared LLLT combined with exercise to placebo phototherapy with exercise, but the abstract does not specify the outcomes or statistical significance of the results.
population_specificity: 22 women with fibromyalgia, divided into placebo and laser groups.
effective_dosage: 808 nm, 100 mW, 4 J, and 142.85 J/cm² (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 8 weeks, with sessions three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) applied to auriculotherapy points could reduce postoperative pain following lower third molar extractions.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between LLLT and the control group in pain reduction or other postoperative parameters (edema, mouth opening, dysphagia, infection). LLLT did not prevent postoperative pain in this experimental model.
population_specificity: 42 healthy patients undergoing bilateral, symmetrical lower third molar extractions.
study_duration: 21-day interval with LLLT administered immediately postoperatively and repeated at 24 and 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the immediate effect of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMt) on inflammation and pain in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that active PBMt significantly reduced pain (measured by VAS) and levels of TNF-α and IL-8 compared to placebo, but no effect was observed on IL-6 levels.
population_specificity: 18 post-surgical hip arthroplasty patients (divided into placebo and active PBMt groups).
effective_dosage: 40.3 J per point applied to 5 points along the incision (using a device with nine diodes: one 905 nm super-pulsed laser, four 875 nm infrared LEDs, and four 640 nm red LEDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) compared to placebo in relieving pain and improving functional outcomes in patients with temporomandibular disorder (TMD).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT effectively reduced pain and improved temporomandibular joint function, with significant short-term pain relief observed. However, dosage analyses showed inconsistent results regarding the effects of high versus low doses.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular disorder (TMD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (discrepant results on high vs. low doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of using low-level laser therapy (LLLT) or photodynamic therapy (PDT) in the treatment of denture stomatitis (DS) by reviewing high-quality published articles.
results_summary: Based on the available RCTs, LLLT has a significant role in the clinical treatment of DS, while PDT results were similar to conventional antifungal therapies. Four studies were deemed sufficiently reliable in methodology and randomization.
population_specificity: Elderly denture wearers with denture stomatitis (DS).
effective_dosage: Wavelength varied from 455 nm to 830 nm; highest energy exposure was 122 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the attenuation of red light (660 nm) in gingival tissue to inform optimal parameters for antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) or photobiomodulation.
results_summary: The study found that at a 3 mm distance from the laser probe, light intensity attenuated by 50% in both frontal and occlusal views, suggesting significant light loss in gingival tissue. These findings highlight the need to account for attenuation when setting therapy parameters.
population_specificity: 30 patients with chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Laser source with a radiant power output of 100 mW.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy in the management and prevention of recurrent herpes labialis (RHL).
results_summary: The study reviewed six clinical trials and found that low-level laser therapy may be a potential treatment for RHL, but due to marked heterogeneity, no statistical analysis was performed. The wavelengths, power output, and energy density varied widely across studies.
population_specificity: Individuals with recurrent herpes labialis (RHL).
effective_dosage: Wavelengths: 632.5-870 nm; Power output: 5-80 W; Energy density: 2.04-48 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if low-level laser therapy could effectively reduce irritability and other symptoms associated with autistic spectrum disorder in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy significantly reduced irritability, with positive effects maintained and enhanced over time, as measured by the ABC irritability subscale and CGI scales. The adjusted mean difference in irritability scores was -15.17, statistically significant (p < 0.0001).
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 5-17 years with autistic spectrum disorder.
effective_dosage: Eight 5-minute procedures administered to the base of the skull and temporal areas over 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of conducting a full-scale randomized controlled trial to test the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to conventional therapy for managing breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
results_summary: The study found high treatment adherence and satisfaction among participants receiving LLLT, but clinical outcomes did not show additional benefits over conventional therapy alone. No serious adverse reactions were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL) recruited via lymphedema therapists in New Zealand.
effective_dosage: Wavelength: 980/810 nm (80:20 ratio); output power: 500 mW; beam spot size: 5 cm (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of non-surgical treatments for androgenetic alopecia, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), and identify the most effective options.
results_summary: The study found LLLT to be the superior treatment among the options analyzed, with relative effects showing better outcomes compared to other treatments. The quality of evidence for LLLT vs. sham was very low, indicating a need for further high-quality trials.
population_specificity: Men and women with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of integrative health modalities, including massage, in managing persistent pain in primary care settings.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that integrative health modalities, such as massage, can be safely used and may provide patients with hope and empowerment, but specific results for massage are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent pain in primary care settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of combined self-administered foot massage and CBT on psychophysiological stress responses in middle-aged women.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in depression, stress, systolic blood pressure, and blood glucose levels after the intervention. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Korean middle-aged women aged 45-64 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of aromatherapy massage on sleep quality and physiological parameters in surgical intensive care patients.
results_summary: Aromatherapy massage significantly improved sleep quality (mean RCSQ score of 53.80 vs. 29.08 in the control group) and resulted in some positive changes in physiological parameters, notably diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Postoperative, unconscious, extubated patients in a surgical intensive care unit without complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary effects of massage and inhalation aromatherapies on chemotherapy-induced acute nausea and vomiting in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that massage aromatherapy significantly reduced nausea severity and incidence of retching compared to the control group, with greater effectiveness than inhalation aromatherapy in later chemotherapy cycles.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 20-minute aromatherapy foot massage before the second, third, and fourth chemotherapy cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent evidence on the utility of integrative medicine, including massage therapy, for managing physical and emotional issues in cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that massage therapy may help manage physical symptoms like fatigue and pain, as well as emotional issues such as anxiety and fear, in cancer survivors. It suggests that integrative therapies, including massage, are appealing to survivors and may reduce symptom burden.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors experiencing late and long-term sequelae of cancer and its treatment.
